III.

BACKGROUND

A.

Sector Description

1.

Overview

4.
PNG occupies the eastern half of New Guinea island and numerous smaller islands. Of
these, Bougainville, New Britain, New Ireland, and Manus are the largest. PNG's population of
4.2  million  is  scattered  and  overwhelmingly  rural:  3.5  million,  or  84  percent,  of  people  live  in
isolated  villages.  Fourteen  of  the  19  provinces  and  the  national  capital  district  in  PNG  are
coastal. The maritime provinces include Bougainville, Central, East and West New Britain, Gulf,
Madang,  Manus,  Milne  Bay,  Morobe,  New  Ireland,  Oro,  Sandaun,  and  Western.  PNG’s
coastline  reaches  about  6,500  kilometers  (km),  much  of  which  is  accessible  only  by  sea.  In
1990,  12  percent  of  the  population  inhabited  the  island  provinces  and  44  percent  the  coastal
provinces.3 Coastal populations have poor access to roads, and communities are often distant
from  airstrips.  Movement  of  goods  and  people  is  primarily  by  sea  for  most  coastal  residents.
PNG has 17 million hectares of reef-covered coastal waters, making it the largest fishing zone in
the Pacific.

5.
As  a  small,  open,  island  economy,  PNG  is  dependent  on  maritime  transport  for  the
development  of  vital  economic  sectors,  markets, and  social  services.  The  maritime  navigation
aids  system  in  PNG  has  deteriorated  over  the  past  10  years  to  a  state  in  which  maritime
transport  is  negatively  affected.  As  a  result  70  of  166  aids  are  nonoperational,  with  14  on
Bougainville  damaged;  43  discontinued  due  to  sustained  vandalism  (i.e.,  all  equipment
repeatedly  removed,  stolen,  or damaged); 9 destroyed  either  through  prolonged  deterioration,
volcanic activity, or by being run down by ships; and 4 out of service due to faulty  equipment.
Most  of  the  damaged  navigation  aids  are  on  PNG’s  most  critical  coastal  routes.  The  existing

6.
About  90  percent of the  world’s  cargo  is transported  by  sea  relying on  nautical  charts.
Consequently, most coastal countries place great importance on their coastal management and

scattered.  Location  of  many  off-lying  islets  may  not  be  accurately  positioned  on  these  charts

2.

Poverty

Eighty-five percent of the PNG population lives in the rural areas fragmented by rugged
7.
terrain  and  inadequate  physical  infrastructure.  The  coastal  communities  rely  on  subsistence
farming and fishing for  their  livelihoods,  supplemented  by  a  small  amount  of  cash  activities—
trading in fish, local produce, and in some areas, copra, palm oil, and betel nut. The agriculture
sector  has  been  stagnant  for  a  long  period,  averaging  growth  of  only  1  percent  per  annum.
Rural  incomes  are  approximately  only  one  tenth  of  those  in  urban  areas.  In  many  coastal
communities,  expansion  of  cash  activities  will  depend  on  improvements  in  marine  transport,
since remoteness and  rugged  terrain  prohibit  construction of a  road network to effectively  link
them to inland areas.

8.
While PNG is classified as a low-middle-income country with a 1998 per capita income
of $890, its social indicators are typical of countries of a much lower income level. According to
the World Bank’s 1999 country assistance strategy for PNG, 37 percent of the population now
live  at  or  below  the  poverty  line,  defined  as  the  minimum  income  required  to  support  a  life-
sustaining nutritional intake. On the United Nations Development Programme’s (UNDP) human
development index, PNG ranks last among Pacific Island countries and 164th of 174 developing
countries.4 These indicators make PNG’s human development level the lowest of ADB's Pacific
developing member countries. The UNDP's 1998 human poverty index value of 72 reflects the
country's poor access to basic services: low life expectancy of 55 years, with about 25 percent
of women not surviving beyond the age of 40, high infant mortality rate (62 per 1,000 live births),
primary  and  secondary  school  enrolment  of  only  55  and  9  percent  respectively,  and  average
literacy of 52 percent (40 percent for women).

9.
The disadvantaged in PNG society are disproportionately female. Girls account for only
33 percent of total school enrolments and women make up only 30 percent of tertiary students.
Rural women have poor access to health care, and life expectancy for rural women is low as a
result of prevailing high  rates of  maternal  mortality,  poor  nutrition,  and  generally  high  rates  of
violence  against  women.  The  World  Bank’s  1999  country  assistance  strategy  estimates  that
violence against women is endemic in PNG with 70 percent of all PNG wives battered by their

3.

Transport

11.
The  transport  system  is  multimodal,  dispersed,  and  in  comparison  with  other  low-  to
medium-income  developing  countries,  undeveloped.  There  are  26,962  km  of  roads;  17
commercial ports; numerous government and private wharves, jetties, and landings; 46 airports;
and  hundreds  of  airstrips.  Geographic  dispersion  of  the  population  and  the  rugged  terrain  in
both inland and coastal areas imply that a significant portion of high-cost transport infrastructure
serves relatively few people.

4.

The Maritime Transport Sector

The  maritime 

transport  sector

infrastructure serving the main urban areas (Kimbe, Lae, Madang,  Port  Moresby, and  Rabaul)
catering  to  both  international  and  coastal  traffic,  and  (ii)  a  large  number  of  lesser  ports  (e.g.,
Alotau,  Kavieng,  Oro  Bay,  Wewak,  and  others)  serving  smaller  vessels  engaged  mainly  in

a.

Demand Patterns

13.
Imports from overseas are delivered to the main ports of Lae and Port Moresby, and are
then distributed throughout the country by road, air, and to the remote coastal communities, by
small  coastal  vessels.  This  means  that  some  minor  ports  are  congested,  but  remain  of  minor
importance  in  terms  of  tonnage.  Over  the past 10  years,  vessel  calls  at  all  PNG’s  ports  have
grown  at  an  average  annual  rate  of  3.3  percent,  rising  to  7,486  in  1998.  Calls  by  overseas
vessels, which doubled to 2,347 in the  same period,  were  responsible for  most  of  the growth,
while coastal vessel traffic growth was relatively stagnant.

14.
The  mix  of  vessel  types  in  PNG  waters  has  significantly  changed  during  the  past  10
years. In particular, in  the  overseas  trade,  the  number  of  calls by  container  ships and  tankers
has more than doubled (from 307 per annum in 1988 to 678 in 1998), while calls by the general
break-bulk  cargo  ships  have  remained  steady,  and  declined  in  proportion  to  other  ship-calls.
Calls by overseas passenger cruise ships are increasing, approximately doubling over the past
10  years,  albeit  from  a  small  base.  The  increase  in  overseas  vessel  traffic  was  recorded  by
ships  carrying forestry products,  rising from  zero  in  1988  to  an  average  of  over  900  calls  per
annum between 1994 and 1998. Forestry, however, has been highly volatile and the increase of
related vessel traffic in PNG waters in recent years cannot be considered permanent.

15.
The  most  frequently  visited  ports  are  Madang  and  Kimbe,  followed  by  Port  Moresby,
Lae, and  Rabaul. Vessel  traffic, however,  does  not  correlate  with  cargo  throughput,  for  which

Kimbe, agricultural exports. Port Moresby and Lae, on the other hand, represent PNG’s primary

16.
Consequently, the priority navigation aids do not only relate to the economic importance
of  the  two  primary  international  ports,  but  also  account  for  the  relatively  heavy  small-vessel
traffic in the areas of the regional ports. Passenger traffic, in particular, is a significant concern,
with the coastal operators moving well over 1,000 people a day between Lae, Madang, Kimbe,
Kavieng,  Buka,  and  numerous  other  minor  ports  in  the  region.  In  addition,  numerous
noncommercial village boats ferry large numbers of passengers by sea, sometimes over great
distances  in  small,  open,  overloaded  craft.  Many  minor  ports  that  serve  this  traffic,  presently
have no navigation aids; this represents a significant risk to passenger safety.

b.

Hydrographic Survey and Charting

Of the 1.7 million km2 of sea area, 10 percent has been adequately surveyed, 5 percent
17.
of which needs to be surveyed again. Eighty-five percent of the area has not been surveyed and
cannot, subsequently, be used for maritime travel. The chart ratings given to the existing charts
produced by the Royal Australian Navy range between AQ-IA under International Hydrographic
Office  (IHO)  standards. While  the  AQ  indicates  that  among  PNG  charts  (i)  some  permit  safe
marine  navigation  of  vessels  routinely  operating  in  any  one  world  maritime  area,  and  that  (ii)
certain  charts  meet  IHO  Standard,  the  IA  rating  signifies  that  many  of  these  charts  are
inadequate, and that charts exist that do not meet the minimum standards and are unacceptable
for safe navigation.

18.
It is only through nautical charts that the navigators can know the depths, location of aids
to navigation, navigable routes, and forces of tidal currents. These allow planning of the safest
and  most  economic  route  from  one  port  to  another.  More  importantly,  navigators  can  locate
alternative  routes  in  case  of  bad  weather  or  to  avoid  grounding.  The  inadequate  charting  of
PNG  waters  has  an  adverse  effect  on  the  economy.  Hazardous  navigation  and  the  poor
condition of navigation aids have translated  into  higher  insurance premiums due  to  the  higher
risks.

19.
Modern technology used in navigation, such as the global positioning system (GPS) and
electronic  chart  display  and  information  system,  requires  a  much  higher  degree  of  accuracy
than  is  provided  in  the  existing  PNG  hydrographic  charts.  Hydrographic  data  is  essential  for
PNG’s maritime and navigational safety; inadequate hydrographic services can lead to delays in
resource  exploration.  In  the  marine  environment,  there  can  be  no  exploitation  of  resources
without exploration; this requires hydrographic data.

c.

Navigation Aids System

21.
Currently,  96  navigation  aids  of  the  total  of  166  are  operational.  Seventy  aids  are
nonoperational,  with  14  in  Bougainville  damaged,  43  aids  discontinued  due  to  sustained
vandalism (i.e., all equipment repeatedly removed, stolen, or damaged), 9 aids with weather or
volcanic  activity-related  deterioration, and 4  out of  service  due  to  faulty  equipment.  Most  aids
are  in  poor  condition  due  to  vandalism,  environmental  deterioration,  age  of  the  installation,
inappropriate  design,  or  inadequate  maintenance.  The  level  of  vandalism  and  environmental
deterioration  correlate  with  the  geographic  location,  with  some  areas  suffering  losses  from
persistent  community  vandalism,  while  other  areas  are  subject  to  severe  annual  weather
patterns  that  accelerate  deterioration  rates.  Most  aids  are  well  below  the  expectations  of
mariners and the needs of the  maritime  transport  system  in PNG. Also,  most  of  the damaged
aids are on PNG’s critical maritime routes. The system of daymarks is not adequate to facilitate
safe  maritime  travel  by  the  island  communities.  Many  of  these  are  in  severe  need  of
rehabilitation.

d.

Major Shipping Routes

22.
PNG  shipping  can  be  categorized  as  (i)  international  through  traffic,  (ii)  coastal  traffic
between the major ports, and (iii) small vessel traffic serving numerous minor ports. About 2,850
vessels per year pass through eastern and northern PNG waters on voyages to Asian ports in
the  Peoples  Republic  of  China,  Japan,  and  Republic  of  Korea.  This  traffic  is  principally  bulk
carriers, container vessels, and general cargo vessels. There is no traffic in crude oil on these
routes.  To  pass  through  the  north  Coral  Sea,  traffic  is  evenly  divided  between  two  routes:
Jomard Entrance or around Rossel Island. Navigation aids on these routes are  vital  and  need
attention.  The  most  frequently  used  routes  are  Jomard–Vitiaz  Strait  for  vessels  heading
northwest  to  Hong  Kong,  China  and  the  Philippines;  Jomard–Vitiaz  Strait  west  of  Manus
Province for  vessels going to the  Republic  of  Korea  and  southwest  Japan;  and  Jomard–Saint
Georges Channel and Rossell northeast of New Ireland Province for vessels on route to Japan.
These routes are reasonably well served with navigation aids and charts. The vessels on these
routes  usually  carry  radar  and  GPS,  and  are  subject  to  inspection  by  safety  authorities.  The
navigation aids on these routes require less attention. Petroleum products are shipped from the
Kumul oil terminal in the Gulf of Papua. This traffic quickly departs PNG waters and heads for
Torres Strait.

i.

Navigation Aids Operations

38.
The objectives of the navigation aids system in PNG, as in other maritime countries, is to
provide  a  nationally  integrated  navigational  support  service  that  meets  international  standards
and  is  responsive  to  the  needs  of  transport  providers  and  users.  In  addition  to  maintaining  a
system of visual and radar navigational markers, the system should provide timely and relevant
navigational and maritime safety information to shipowners. The system should cater not only to
the  economically  most  important  international  and  coastal  routes,  but  also  support  social
services to remote communities.

39.
The present system of navigation aids fails to meet any of these objectives. The technical
audit  of  navigation  aids  carried  out  under  this  study  found  that  of  the  166  aids  in  PNG  waters,
nearly all require urgent remedial attention to structures, lighting, or electrical equipment. Only 58
percent are operating at all, while the remaining 42 percent are nonoperational due to vandalism

ii.

Search and Rescue Operations

41.
The  importance  of  saving  lives  and  property  at  sea  is  reflected  in  the  comprehensive
international  convention  regulations  that  govern  public  maritime  services  provision,  e.g.,
regulations under Safety of Life at Sea and Search and Rescue (SAR) Convention of 1979 under
International  Maritime  Organization.  Shore-based  services  include  constant  radio  monitoring,
operation  of  high-speed  rescue  craft,  and  fire-fighting  equipment,  but  may  extend  to  rescue
helicopters, and medical and similar services. SAR services need to be integrated with shipborne
Safety of Life at Sea equipment. This equipment reflects technological developments in materials
and equipment.  The  International  Maritime  Organization  introduced  the  global  maritime  distress
and safety system (GMDSS) in 1997. Land-based SAR arrangements must include highly efficient
coordination facilities, full-time monitoring services of radio distress frequencies, and of course the
means to offer help at short notice and at high speed, which means life craft and helicopters on
constant standby. If there are offshore platforms in the zone, the SAR organization must also be
equipped to deal with emergency calls from them.

42.
The  SAR  function  within  MSB  receives  a  notification  of  missing  persons  at  sea,  and
investigates and activates a search pattern if deemed necessary. The SAR coordinator has SAR
resources  available  for  rescue  missions.  These  involve  funding  for  commercial  aircraft  services
provided  on  regular  flights  in  the  region,  or  hiring  of  a  fixed-wing  aircraft  or  helicopters  to
implement a search pattern. Delays are frequently experienced in reporting the  missing persons
resulting in an expansion of the  search area.  A draft cooperative agreement between PNG and
Australia is under consideration for undertaking joint-SAR missions. This document  corresponds
to the requirements of (i) the Convention on International Civil Aviation 1944, (ii) the International
Convention on Maritime Search and Rescue 1979, (iii) the International Convention on Safety of
Life at Sea 1974, and (iv) the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea 1982.

2.

The Maritime Safety Authority

58.
Promulgation of  the  submitted  Maritime  Safety  bill  commences  a  second  phase  under
the sector restructuring program. Principles that govern establishment of the MSA include that
(i)  maritime  safety  remains  a  public  sector  responsibility,  (ii)  all  maritime  safety  functions  be
combined into one organization, (iii) this organization be financially  self-sufficient  with  services
provided on a user-pay basis, and (iv) as a body corporate, the MSA will have the ability to sue
and  be  sued  and  have  the  legal  capacity  to  address  landowner  leases  and  service  contracts
within the legal framework established by the Land Act 1996. The Project will finalize the MSA
act  and  the  related  amendments  in  affected  acts,  and  prepare,  activate,  and  guide
implementation of the MSA.

59.
The legislation establishing the MSA will enable the MSA to raise its own revenue from
fees  and  charges,  to  retain  this  revenue  in  accounts  in  its  own  name,  and  to  apply  these
revenues  to  the  maritime  safety functions  specified  in  its  legislation.  The financial  objective  of
the  MSA  will  be  to  meet  all  of  its  own  expenses,  including  any  future  financing  of  capital
requirements,  from  its  own  revenues.  The  MSA  will  undertake  a  range  of  activities  that  are
related to the provision of maritime safety, including provision and maintenance of navigation aids,
vessel  surveys  and  registration,  port  state  control,  and  management  of  the  national  oil  spill
contingency plan, and search and rescue operations. Revenues associated with these functions
will,  consequently,  become  part  of  the  MSA's  income.  The  Project  includes  establishment  of
national hydrographic services, and the cost of maintaining this function over the longer term will
be borne by the MSA. The MSA will also coordinate national search and rescue operations. Both
of these functions generate additional benefits for a wide range of beneficiaries in addition to the
commercial  shipping  industry.  Consistent  with  practice  in  other  countries,  additional  funding

5.

Hydrographic Capacity

82.
As with other coastal nations, PNG depends  heavily on the marine environment and the
resources of its coastal waters. An estimated 50 percent of the population lives on the coastline
adjacent  to  these  waters,  with  direct  reliance  on  the  near-shore  marine  environment  for
subsistence  fishing  and  food,  transport,  and  waste  disposal,  particularly  in  rural  and  regional
areas.  At  the  national  level,  PNG’s  economic  resources  are  densely  concentrated  in  coastal
regions  with  major  economic  dependencies  linked  to  marine  resources  including  tourism,
commercial fisheries and aquaculture, international and domestic shipping, port development, and
hydrocarbon and mineral exploration. Combined with the fragile nature of the coral reef and other
ecosystems in these waters, it is vital that these marine resources be managed in a sustainable
way to support the subsistence needs of regional communities and for sustained economic growth
into the future.

83. While the land-mass is  relatively  well mapped  with  many geographic  information  system
(GIS)  data  sets  available  to  support  policy  and  decision  making  for  land-based  resources  and
environmental management issues, 95 percent of the internal waters of rivers and coastal waters
remain unsurveyed at modern standards. PNG currently lacks the basic charts, coral reef maps,
and data sets that are required for effective management of these critical resources. The Project
aims  to  address  this  by  providing  the  basic  infrastructure,  database,  data,  and  training  as  a
foundation for development and implementation of a national integrated coastal marine resource
management program.

84.
PNG does not have a hydrographic and mapping function. The Royal Australian Navy has
been carrying out hydrographic survey and chart compilation of PNG’s waters. These have been
recompiled  from  older  charts  of  different  publishers  into  nautical  charts.  The  current  charts  that
cover  the  PNG  waters  originate  in  Australia  and  United  Kingdom.  Hydrographic  basic  data  is
generally from before 1944. Under the Project, the PNG Hydrographic Unit of MSB would emerge
with  the  capacity  to  undertake  hydrographic  surveys  and  marine  resource  management.  The
outputs  include  IHO-standard  navigational  charts;  electronic  navigational  charts;  nautical
publications; and delimitation of PNG’s territorial sea, contiguous zone, and exclusive  economic
zone to discharge its legal obligations under the United Nations Convention of the Law of the Sea
(UNCLOS 82).

 19

Additional  output  is  an  integrated  coastal  marine  resource  management  program
85.
supported by a fully operational marine resource database with capacity to maintain and use the
database  and  GIS.  The  program  would  network  DOTCA  with  the  University  of  Papua  New
Guinea,  University  of  Technology  in  Lea  and Port  Moresby,  and  Maritime  College  in  Madang,
and  impact  on  key  government  and  nongovernment  stakeholder  agencies  responsible  for

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

About  half  of  the  population  of  PNG  live  in  the  coastal  provinces,  most  of  them  in
86.
conditions  of  extreme  isolation,  deprived  of  basic  social  services  and  economic  opportunities.
The delivery of traded food items, education, and health services all depend heavily on ocean
transport.  Integration of the  coastal  communities  with  the national economy,  on  which  income
and  employment  opportunities  in  the  coastal  communities  ultimately  depend,  requires  great
improvement of the frequency, reliability, and safety of coastal maritime transport by commercial
vessels  and  smaller  private  craft.  A  major  constraint  to  this  development  is  the  poor  and
deteriorating level of navigational services provided by the public sector in all coastal areas.

87.
Provision of navigation aids and other maritime safety services is a public good. Failure
to  provide  the  services  has  been  due  to  (i)  a  weak  institutional  environment  and  (ii)  chronic
landowner  frustration  resulting  in  widespread  vandalism  against  navigation  aids  installations.
Vandalism  is  primarily  a  social  problem,  and  secondarily  a  financial  and  technical  problem.
Landowner communities must understand the role of navigation aids in their communities and in
PNG, and must support the network. They are willing to do this provided a  sustained financial
and  social  commitment  to  their  needs  is guaranteed  by  the authority  managing  the  system  of
navigational services.

88.
The  coastal  communities  are  frustrated  with  continuing  impoverishment  and  lack  of
opportunity,  while  the  urban  segment  of  the  economy  grows  in  pace  with  the  increasing
extraction  of  minerals,  petroleum,  and  timber  resources.  The  isolation  of  coastal  communities
from the economy represents a serious economic loss and has become a social challenge. This
has resulted in a breakdown of peace and security conditions across the country, alienation of
disadvantaged communities, and economic disintegration.

89.
Institutional  weakness  is  the  most  serious  deficiency  in  the  maritime  safety  system.  To
improve  maritime  safety  services,  the  Government  will,  through  the  Project,  embark  on  a
comprehensive  sector  improvement  program  to  establish  effective  maritime  safety  services.  Its
objective  is  to  establish  an  autonomous  MSA  that  is  endowed  with  a  sustained  and  efficient
capacity to manage, operate, and maintain the rehabilitated navigation aids, and provide maritime
safety  services  at  international  standards.  This  restructuring  program  is  central  to  improving

 20

management of maritime sector services; the Government will implement the program as part of
its maritime sector strategy.

90.
The  Project  supports  maritime  transport  in  PNG  to  contribute  its  full  potential  to
economic  growth  and  development  of  the  country.  The  Project  is  designed  to  (i)  restructure
maritime  sector  management  to  enable  provision  of  sustainable  and  effective  maritime  safety
services;  (ii)  lower  the  cost of  maritime  transport,  and  improve  safety  of  cargo  and passenger
movements into and between urban areas; (iii) improve the distribution of goods and services,
and support the development of markets; and (iv) generate income opportunities in remote and
impoverished coastal rural areas.

B.

Objectives and Scope

91.
The objective of the Project is to contribute to economic growth by releasing the potential
of the maritime transport  sector. Specifically,  the Project  supports  (i)  geographic  integration  of
the  country,  including  remote  populations;  (ii)  distribution  of  goods  and  services  to  the  rural
poor; (iii) improved affordability, reliability, and safety in travel along the coastal areas; and (iv)
development of local markets, and increasing efficiency of trade with domestic and international
centers. The Project will significantly raise the confidence of mariners navigating in PNG coastal
waters  and  enable  them  to  provide  improved  transportation  services  at  lower  cost  and  lower
risk.

92.
The  Project  will  (i)  restructure  sector  management  by  implementing  an  autonomous
MSA, (ii) reconstruct the network of the navigation aids to an acceptable international maritime
standard,  (iii)  establish  a  self-reliant  hydrographic  service,  and  (iv)  institutionalize  sustainable
operation and maintenance of the navigation aids, and (v) implement community programs that
contribute  to  effective  network  maintenance.  The  scope  of  the  Project  includes  the  following
components: sector reorganization; construction of new channels, restoration and rehabilitation
of  navigation  aids;  provision  of  equipment  for  navigation  aids;  development  of  community
engagement program; establishment of hydrographic infrastructure and management capacity;
provision of training; and project management.

5.

Establishment of Hydrographic Infrastructure and Management Capacity

99.
Hydrographic charts are primary navigation tools. Accurate  charts  allow  vessels  to use
the  differential  global  positioning  system  (DGPS).  Inaccurate  charts  do  not  allow  the  use  of
DGPS, and consequently prohibit night navigation in some areas, lead to increased risk of reef
collisions,  require  larger  quantities  of  expensive  navigation  aids,  and  prohibit  comprehensive
understanding of national marine resources.

100.
The  Project  will  establish  basic  infrastructure  and  equipment,  institutional  framework
within the MSA with joint programs with the PNG defense forces, and management capacity to
support  implementation  of  a  hydrographic  unit.  The  unit  will  implement  a  marine  resource
database  to  support  decision  making  on  marine  resource  management,  an  interagency
institutional framework to support integrated usage of the data by all stakeholders, sustainable
upgrading of skills in GIS database management, application of IHO standards in the production
of navigational charts for the rivers and coastal waters, identification of baseline information to
confirm  PNG’s  territorial  waters  and  exclusive  economic  zone  under  the  United  Nations
Convention  of  the  Law  of  the  Sea  (UNCLOS  82),  and  promotion  of  data  availability  for  all
relevant users.

A.

Economic Analysis

1. 

Least-Cost Analysis

128.
The technical solutions under the Project have been selected using a least-cost analysis of
three possible technological options: (i) fixed navigation visual and radar aids (navigation aids), (ii)
electronic  navigation  systems,  and  (iii)  compulsory  pilotage.  Of  these  three  options,  fixed
navigation aids are considered the most feasible option for PNG. Electronic systems rely on, and
generally  complement,  a  well-functioning  navigation  aids  system,  not  replace  it.  The  use  of
electronic  systems  is  severely  constrained  by  inadequate  telecommunication  and  information
technology  standards,  affordability,  maintenance  requirements,  and 
the  poor  quality  of
hydrographic charts. Compulsory pilotage is cumbersome and  impractical,  and still  relies on the
provision of a system of navigation aids.

2.

situations  with  and  without  the  Project.  The  economic  costs  of  the  six  project  components

C.

Risks

136.
The Project is not subject to any unusual risks. The main risks are (i) economic shocks—
downturns  in  international  trade  and  the  economy,  and  (ii)  the  shortage  of  counterpart  funds.
The  risk  of  economic  shocks  has  been  reduced  as  a  result  of  the  Government’s  recent
economic  policies.  With  regard  to  counterpart  funding,  the  Government's  current  policy
emphasizes the importance of transport safety and effective utilization of existing infrastructure
assets.  The  project  design  seeks  to  minimize  the  risk  of  insufficient  counterpart  funds  by
combining design features and preventive conditions. These include establishment of navigation
aids  trust  accounts  that  would  hold  revenues  from  the  light  dues  and  increasingly  finance
operation  and  maintenance  of  the  navigation  aids  network.  Land  acquisition  issues  are
addressed as one of the main project components; the Project aims to establish a system under
which land acquisition claims would be paid under a more acceptable format  than  in  the past.
The  Project  also  addresses  important  endemic  challenges  to  establishing  efficient  maritime
safety  services,  including  the  need  to  resolve  institutional  issues  and  recurring  vandalism.
These risk areas were identified early in the project development process and realistic programs
for institutional change and community development have been devised in detail.

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS OF THE MARITIME SAFETY AUTHORITY

A. 

Assumptions in Revenue Estimation

1.

Income Sources

1.
The  principal  revenue  sources  for  the  Maritime  Safety  Authority  (MSA)  will  be  the
navigation aids dues (known as ‘light dues') and Protection of the Sea levy (POSL). Light dues
for both domestic and international vessels were recently increased effective 1 January 2000
by  75  percent  to  K60  per  meter  for  vessels  paying  annually.  The  navigation  aids  dues  are
expected  to  remain  at  the  current  levels  until  2002,  and  that,  in  line  with  the  proposal  of  the
Department of Transport and Civil Aviation (DOTCA), a POSL of K0.30 per net registered ton
(nrt) per quarter will be introduced prior to the establishment of  the  Maritime  Safety  Authority
(MSA).

A  total  revenue  from  minor  sources  relating  to  services  of  the  MSA,  including  survey
2.
fees,  chart  sales,  and  vessel  registration  fees,  is  estimated  at  K0.16  million  in  2001.  These
revenues  are  assumed  to  grow  in  real  terms  at  the  same  rate  as  the  domestic  vessel  fleet.
Revenue from hydrographic services (chart sales and the sale of data) is assumed to increase
over  five  years  to  about  four  times  the  current  level,  reflecting  establishment  of  the  national
hydrographic  capability  and  development  of  an  appropriate  pricing  regime.  All  charges  are
adjusted every two years for inflation.

Cash balances held by the MSA are assumed to be invested from time to time and the
3.
interest credited to the MSA’s account. The interest rate on such investments is included at 5
percent per annum.

2. 

Vessels Volumes

i. 

International Vessels Calling at Papua New Guinea ports

All  commercial  international  vessels  calling  in  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG)  ports  are
4.
assumed to pay both the navigation aids dues (light dues) and the proposed POSL. Total calls
of overseas vessels increased steadily from 1,179 in 1988 to 3,159 per annum in 1996, before
the Asian crisis precipitated a sharp decline to 2,347 in 1998. While official data for 1999 and
the first half of 2000 is not available, with recovery of most Asian economies a resurgence in
vessel numbers can be confidently expected. The number of calls in 2001 has been assumed
to be 3,147—the same number as in 1997.

5.
 Eighty percent of overseas vessel calls are assumed to be made by vessels paying the
annual fee: the remainder of calls are by vessels paying on a per voyage basis. On average,
these vessels are assumed to make three calls per quarter. These assumptions are consistent
with the amount of revenue that has been collected from overseas vessels by the Papua New
Guinea Harbour Board (PNGHB).

ii.

Kumul Oil Terminal

6.
Based on navigation dues payments for the last five years, 60 vessels use the Kumul
oil terminal each year. All vessels calling at the Kumul oil terminal pay their light dues on a per

voyage basis, implying that individual vessels will not make more than three voyages per year.
Each  vessel  is  therefore  assumed  to  pay  both  navigation  aids  dues  and  the  POSL  on  each
call.

iii.

Domestic

7.
About 420 domestic vessels registered in PNG exceed 15 meters (m) in length, and are
thus required to pay navigation aid dues. About 60 percent of these exceed 24 m in length—
the  proposed  threshold  for  the  POSL.  Fifty  percent  of  the  vessels  required  to  pay  light  dues
are assumed to pay the POSL.

8.
Overseas  and  international  vessels  average  3,231  nrt  and  553  nrt,  respectively.  A
figure of 60,000 per vessel—appropriate for vessels averaging 240 m in length  was  used  for
callers at the Kumul oil terminal.

3.

Vessel size

4.

Growth rates

Overseas  vessel  calls  are  estimated  to  increase  by  3.7  percent  per  year:  This  is  one
9.
half  of  the  geometric  average  growth  rate  experienced  during  1988-1998,  and  approximates
the  long-term  growth  rate  of  international  maritime  trade.  The  average  vessel  size  in
international trade increases by 2 percent per annum. The growth rate for the domestic fleet is
estimated at 1.7 percent, in line with experience of the last decade. Exports from the Kumul oil
terminal were assumed to remain at their current level throughout the forecast period.

5.

Effectiveness of Revenue Collection

10.
Evidence  suggests  effectiveness  of  revenue  collection  can  be  improved.  The  Project
includes  components  aimed  at  enhancing  revenue  collection  effectiveness.  Experience  with
the  collection  of  similar  dues  in  other  countries  suggests  that,  if  properly  implemented,  the
payment  of  light  dues  will  be  difficult  to  evade,  and  with  the  proposed  support,  a  very  high
proportion of potential revenues can be realized. Eighty-five percent of the revenues due from
light  dues  and  the  POSL  are  assumed  to  be  collected  in  2001,  95  percent  in  2002,  and  99
percent in 2003 and the subsequent years.

B. 

Assumptions Operating Expenses Estimation

1.

Salary Costs

11.
A summary of all operating expenses is  given  in  Table  A5.  A  first  draft  organizational
structure for the MSA was developed to estimate staff costs. This structure includes a total of
50 permanent positions: 17 less than the staff complement of the Maritime Division of DOTCA
(excluding  the  crew  of  Kulasi  and  Sepura).  Salary  levels  within  the  Maritime  Safety  Branch
(MSB)  are  low,  and  the  salary  scale  compressed.  As  a  result,  MSB  has  difficulty  retaining
qualified and experienced staff  in  technical  and  managerial  positions.  This  problem  needs  to
be  addressed  if  the  MSA  is  to  be  effective.  Thus,  the  assumed  salaries  will  in  general  be
higher than those  currently  paid  by  MSB.  The  differential  is  higher  for  more  senior  positions,
ranging  from  20  percent  for  base  grade  administrative  support  staff  to  60  percent  at  senior

Corporate Expenses

12.
Corporate  expenses  include  the  salaries  of  the  chief  executive  officer  as  well  as  the
three divisional directors, the salaries of other corporate services offices, including accounting
staff. The financial analysis also includes a K21,000 per year allowance for board fees, based
on a 7-member board meeting monthly and a sitting fee of K250 per day. Annual rental costs
are estimated at K250,000 per year—in line with current rental costs at K21,000 per month. An
allowance  of  K70,000  per  year  for  office  expenses  includes  provision  for  30  desktop
computers  and  10  networked  printers  with  a  replacement  cycle  of  three  years,  as  well  as
K25,000 per year for general office expenses.

3.

Navigational Aids Maintenance Costs

13.
Estimates for the several nonsalary cost components for navigational aids maintenance
include cost of  spare  parts,  estimated  at  K200,000  per  year,  and  cost  of  training  at  K50,000
per year. A comprehensive review of efficient logistics for the MSA is included under the sector
reorganization component of the Project. The logistics support would be purchased in a cost-
effective way from private providers through a competitive process. Costs are based on a daily
vessel hire rate of K4,500 per day  (inclusive  of  fuel),  and  helicopter  hire  rates  of  K2,400  per
flying hour. The services of a navigation aids vessel would be required for 150 days per year,
and helicopter flying time for  20 hours per year. A total  of  100  days  of  vehicle  hire  has  been
allowed.  The  total  costs  of  logistics  support  for  navigational  aids  maintenance  has  therefore
been estimated at K735,000 per year. The cost of training, transport, and spare parts for the
navigational aids are assumed from the Project for the duration of the Project. These expenses
are therefore attributed to the MSA budget from 2006 onward.

Community Program

A community engagement program is a central to the strategy for reducing vandalism.
14.
Five  full-time  staff  positions  are  allocated  for  the  program  with  salary  costs  estimated  at

all, would be covered by community contracts. These are assumed to increase to 180 by 2004,
and remain at that level thereafter.

Key Assumptions of the Analysis

OIL SPILL LEVY

All  commercial  international  vessels  calling  in  Papua  New  Guinea  (PNG)  ports  are
1.
assumed to pay the levy. Total overseas commercial vessel calls increased steadily from 1,179
in  1998  to  3,159  per  annum  in  1996,  before  the  Asian  crisis  precipitated  a  sharp  decline  to
2,347  in  1998.  Although  official  data  for  1999  and  the  first  half  of  2000  is  not  available,  with
recovery  now  established  in  most  Asian  economies  a  resurgence  in  vessel  numbers  can  be
confidently expected. The number of calls in 2001  has  been assumed  to  be  3,147—the  same
number as in 1997. It is assumed that overseas vessels make, on average, 3 calls per quarter.
Sixty  vessels  use  the  Kumul  oil  terminal  per  year,  all  of  which  pay  their  light  dues  on  a  per
voyage basis, implying that individual vessels make  less  than  three  voyages per  year.  The  oil
spill  levy  would  therefore  assumed  be  paid  on  each  call.  About  420  domestic  vessels  are
registered in PNG, of which 60 percent exceed 24 meters (m) in length. About 50 percent of the
registered fleet has been used in the revenue estimates.

B.

Vessel size and Growth Rates

2.
Average net registered tonnages (nrts) for overseas and international vessels are 3,231
and  553,  respectively.  Vessels  calling  at  Kumul  oil  terminal  are  60,000.  Calls  by  overseas
vessels  are  assumed  to  grow  by  3.7  percent  per  annum.  The  average  vessel  size  in  the
international trade increases by 2 percent per annum.

C.

Costs

3.
The purchase value of oil spill equipment is K3.5 million. The depreciation period of eight
years was retained. Staff costs are K180,000 per  year  including  salary  and  benefits based  on
six full-time equivalent positions with an average full-time remuneration package of K30,000 per
year. An allowance of 10 percent has been included to cover office and administrative expenses
adding about K116,000 to the  budget  in  the first  year.  An  inflation  allowance of 5  percent per
annum has been included in the estimation of all future cost components. Costs relating directly
to individual incidents are generally recoverable from the responsible party. The majority of the
costs  included  in  the  analysis  are,  therefore,  associated  with  maintaining  the  response
capability, and are, as a consequence, fixed. The anticipated increase in ship traffic will result in
increased  revenues,  while  it  will  not  add  significantly  to  the  agency’s  costs.  The  analysis,
therefore, assumes that the levy will be held constant in nominal terms throughout the forecast
period, despite the increase in inflation.

D.

Revenue Collection

4.
The proposed levy should be collected along with light dues. The analysis has assumed
that 85 percent of the revenue would be collected in 2001, rising to 95 percent in 2002 and to 99
percent thereafter.

2.
The  least-cost  analysis  of  the  Project  has  considered  three  alternative  technologies  to
meet  the  required  safety  and  efficiency  improvements  for  maritime  navigation:  (i)  fixed
navigational  visual  and  radar  aids,  (ii)  electronic  navigation  systems,  and  (iii)  compulsory

B.

Least-Cost Alternatives

1.

Fixed Navigational Visual Aids

Traditionally,  maritime navigation has  relied exclusively  on  visual  sightings  to  establish
3.
vessel position.  For coastal  navigation,  natural  or  artificially  derived  visual,  and  more  recently
radar, aids located on land or water mark navigable channels and warn of submerged hazards,
while  celestial  aids—the  sun,  moon,  and  stars—have  been  used  to  navigate  through  open
waters. For several centuries, purposefully constructed navigation aids have been the mainstay
of coastal maritime navigation, guiding vessels through shallow and difficult waters. Worldwide,
networks of navigation aids remain a primary coastal navigation tool.

Current navigation aids technology includes the use of high intensity, low voltage electric
4.
lighting  systems.  Most  navigation  aids  are  solar  powered,  and  capable  of  providing  high
performance light without the need for costly refueling. The navigation aids  generally  allow for
several  years’  operability  with  minimal  annual  or  semiannual  maintenance.  Structures
supporting the navigation aids are usually simple in design:  concrete pile  structures  located  in
shallow water, floating buoys in deeper water, or towers on land.

5.
Navigation  aids  provide  visual  signals  to  mariners,  enabling  them  to  fix  position,  and
guide  them  through  difficult  waters  or  into  port.  In  addition,  some  navigation  aids  incorporate
radar transponder beacons (racons), allowing mariners to sight navigation aids in poor visibility.
A navigation aids system is fundamental to maritime navigation, and its use is second nature to
all  mariners.  Every  maritime  nation  maintains  a  navigation  aids  system;  this  is  considered  an
international obligation.

2.

Electronic Navigation Systems

Advancements  over  the  past  two  decades  have  resulted  in  use  of  global  positioning
6.
systems (GPS) by the maritime industry. Based on satellite technology, these systems provide
accurate  positioning  in  many  parts  of  the  world.  Where  coastal  hydrographic  charts  are
accurate, commercially available GPS systems can establish positions in charted waters to an
accuracy  of  a  few  meters.  Use  of  a  GPS  system  requires  commensurately  accurate
hydrographic charts and provision of a GPS receiver system on board vessels.

In practice, the system relies on the functioning of sophisticated equipment and accurate
7.
coastal  charts.  The  charts  available  for  PNG’s  coastal  waters  are  not  sufficiently  accurate  to
permit reliance on a GPS for practical navigation purposes. Moreover, systems such as this fail
occasionally, and backup systems must be concurrently available. For this reason, and due to
mariners’ instinctive reliance on visual sightings, GPS and other similar electronic systems are
always  complemented  by  a  fully  functioning  navigation  aids  network  of  navigation  aids.  Even
with  the  most  sophisticated  onboard  GPS  system,  mariners  always  check  vessel  position
through visual sightings, wherever possible.

8.
These systems are, therefore, complementary and additional to a network of navigation
aids, and are not an alternative to fixed navigation aids. This is the case even in the most highly
developed  nations,  where  navigation  aids  continue  to  play  a  key  role  in  maritime  navigation.
This  is  particularly  relevant  in  PNG,  due  to  the  low  level  of  technological  capabilities,
affordability constraints, maintenance difficulties, and poor quality of hydrographic charts.

3.

Compulsory Pilotage

9.
In  areas  of  difficult,  complex,  or  crowded  waters,  the  use  of  pilots  is  sometimes
compulsory. In this case, a specially trained pilot will take control of a vessel and steer it through
a  specified area.  Pilots are  considered  experts  in  their  jurisdictional  waters,  often  to  the  point
that  they  no  longer  need  the  guidance  of  local  navigation  aids.  It  is  theoretically  possible
therefore, that a comprehensive system of compulsory pilotage could be established to replace
navigation aids over part or all of the system.

In practice, however, compulsory pilotage would clearly be impractical as a replacement
10.
for  the  entire  network  of  navigation  aids.  First,  pilots  still  need  to  rely  on  navigation  aids,  no
matter how experienced they are in certain areas. Second, with over 7,000 recorded sailings per
year of larger ships alone, the pilotage capacity required to avoid navigational bottlenecks would
be far greater than could be achieved in practice.

4.

Conclusions

The provision of a network of navigation aids is considered a viable option. It provides a
11.
reliable,  low-technology  solution,  which  has  proven  sustainability  and  applicability  to  PNG.  A
network  of  navigation  aids  currently  exists  within  PNG,  and  with  careful  rehabilitation,
expansion,  and  support  can  provide  a  long-term  solution  for  navigational  needs.  While  the
provision of GPS or similar systems may be appropriate for PNG in the future, it should be seen
only  to  complement  a  navigation  aids  network,  not  replace  it.  The  alternative  of  exclusive
compulsory pilotage is not considered a viable option, and would also only complement parts of
the  network,  not  replace  it.  In  conclusion,  establishing  and  maintaining  a  navigation  aids
network  is  the  least-cost  technically  acceptable  option  to  provide  the  required  navigational
improvements.  Project activities  have  therefore  focused  on  the  development  of  an  affordable,
appropriate system for the existing maritime sector.

23.

Hydrographic Services

28.
The Project establishes a national hydrographic service and a PNG hydrographic office
(PNGHO)  within  the  Department  of  Transport  and  Civil  Aviation  (DOTCA)  and  later  with  the
maritime safety authority (MSA). This will enable the PNGHO to carry out a full range of marine
survey,  database  management,  and  maritime  navigational  charting  functions,  and  produce
accurate nautical charts beginning in the fourth quarter of 2001. Chart production is maintained
at a steady rate, allowing the PNGHO to address charting priorities in PNG waters by the end of
the project period (2006). Apart from enhancing general maritime safety in PNG coastal waters,
there  are  a  number  of  areas  of  national  interest  in  which  a  strengthened  charting  capability
would play an important role, some carry significant economic benefits.

1. 

Marine Boundary Delineation

29.
Most  of  the  existing  nautical  charts  of  PNG’s  coastline  are  old,  inaccurate,  and
inconsistent with GPS satellite data. In particular, the precise boundaries of PNG’s 12-mile limit
and its 200-mile exclusive economic zone (EEZ) are not known. The relevant charts needed to
depict  these  boundaries,  produced  using  varying  methods,  are  not  consistent  with  reference
points.  As  a  result,  it  is  not  possible  to  determine  the  location  of  these  boundaries  to  enable
prosecution  of  foreign  vessels  that  may  be  infringing  PNG’s  rights  in  these  waters.  With
assistance from the Forum Fisheries Agency in Honiara, the PNG National Mapping Bureau is
conducting  a  study  of  the  relevant  charts  to  define  areas  of  survey  needs  to  identify  the
boundaries and reference points. A strengthened PNGHO is vital to carrying out these surveys
and producing the updated boundary charts.

Fisheries

The  emerging  local  fishing  industry  is  mainly  long-liner  fishing  for  sashimi-grade  tuna
31.
within PNG’s exclusive economic zone. At present, 34 locally owned long-liner boats exist, each
with  an  average  of  10  crew,  with  an  annual  catch  valued  at  about  $30  million.7  All  long-line

32.
Most hydrographic charts used by the long-liners around Port Moresby are outdated and
have been corrected on an ad hoc basis by the ships’ captains, using their GPS. Potential new
